results.title: Songlines: contemporary aboriginal music
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Introduction to the Music Industry. Module 4.6. Contemporary Australian Aboriginal music has become an international presence in recent years. This program profiles artists who have taken their brand of indigenous music to the world: Yothu Yindi, Archie Roach and Tiddas. Traditional elements are incorporated into contemporary styles. This is not simply a matter of throwing in the odd didjeridu and clap stick, but rather the traditional cultural role of Aboriginal music as an educational medium is maintained and extended to cover new, important issues and themes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions

results.title: From sand to celluloid
results.creator_credit: Bill McCrow, Warwick Thornton, Darlene Johnson, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Richard Frankland, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: An impressive collection of Australian short films by Indigenous filmmakers which explore the history and contradictions of Aboriginal identity. Richard Frankland’s “No Way to Forget” is the story of a young man, working on the Royal Commission on Black Deaths in Custody, who drives home to Melbourne and is haunted by the ghosts of the dead. dead. In Sally Riley’s “Fly Peewee Fly!”, a young boy teaches his white grandmother and his Koorie father a few lessons on perspective. Rima Tamou’s “Round Up” is a tender story about two country boys who discover that their racial differences are not so acute when they are confronted with the multiculturalism and subcultures of the inner-city. In “Two Bob Mermaid” Darlene Johnson presents a beautifully filmed story about a young girl who can pass for white in a racially divided 1957 Australia. Warwick Thornton’s “Payback” presents a surreal story of a young convict who has to obey tribal lore as much as he does white law. Bill McCrow’s “Black Man Down” explores the need for contemporary Aborigines to be aware of the lessons and spirituality of the past.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill McCrow, Warwick Thornton, Darlene Johnson, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Richard Frankland, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Vacant possession
results.creator_credit: Margot Nash, John Winter, Australian Film Commission, As If Productions and Wintertime Films
results.brief_description: Following her mother’s death, Tessa returns to Australia and to her family home, a sun bleached weatherboard adjacent to Botany Bay. She confronts the collected debris of memory; the fears, the tears and the spectre of the father who forced her flee. Tessa’s home is close to that of an Aboriginal family she knew as a child. During her 20 year absence the nation has changed but not that house. In confronting her father, both the real and the remembered amidst the remains of the old home, the past and present collide in a maelstrom of unexpected ramifications. A brooding and atmospheric piece of cinema, Margot Nash’s first feature is an ambitious drama addressing hearth and place, rememberance and regret in a contemporary setting. Starring Pamela Rabe, John Stanton, Toni Scanlon, Linden Wilkinson, Rita Bruce and Olivia Patten.

results.title: Walking together; Talkin' business; Making things right
results.creator_credit: Lew Griffiths and Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation
results.brief_description: These three programs and a kit aim to support the Council of Aboriginal Reconciliation’s vision for a united Australia “which respects this land of ours; values Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage and provides justice and equity for all.” ‘Walking together’ and ‘Talkin’ Business’ highlights the aims and operation of the Council and ‘Making things right’ discusses the implications of the Mabo decision.

results.title: When dreaming paths meet
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing and Community Services and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description: This program aims to promote Cross-Cultural Awareness and explores situations in which the actions of Aboriginal people have been misinterpreted by non-Aboriginal people in a work environment. Three scenarios highlight body language differences in a youth custody situation, bereavement issues and community relations. At the conclusion of each scene, Richard Frankland summarises and discusses pro-active measures that can be implemented to prevent such Cross-Cultural problems occurring in the future. Designed to be used by non-Aboriginal professionals to promote an understanding of cultural issues.

results.title: Urban Aboriginal artists
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
While the three artists in this video cannot speak for all city-based Aboriginal artists, they raise issues central to the art-making of urban Aboriginals and the problems and controversies surrounding such art. They discuss issues of identity, their views on differences between black and white Australians and social issues of concern to their communities. Michael Riley has a growing reputation as a photographer and film maker, portraying the myths and misconceptions of Aboriginality. Trevor Nickolls has developed a strong iconography in his paintings which attempt to reconcile his black and white heritage. Jeffrey Samuels portrays his cultural heritage through his paintings using contemporary techniques, reflecting on stereotypes, tradition and nature.

results.title: Aboriginal women artists
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
The images by the four Aboriginal women artists in this video program challenge old steroetypes that have seen the artistic activities of Aboriginal women as limited to crafts and body decoration. They use media techniques with which Western artists are familiar but the imagery is distinctively their own revealing the artist’s Aboriginality, whether she lives in a tradition-oriented community or an urban environment. Banduk Marika produces linocuts and fabric designs often involving stories from her clan group. Fiona Foley works in a variety of contemporary media to produce work about her history and against popular stereotypes of Aboriginal people. Bronwyn Bancroft is known for her fabrics, fashion designs and paintings utilizing images of her family and Koori heritage. Euphemia Bostock has helped bring international attention to Koorie fashion design and art through her teaching and practice.

results.title: Tradition and change: art from the desert
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
In the past two decades Aboriginal art has flourished and diversified to a phenomenal extent. A many-faceted art movement has developed, with artists from communities all around Australia contributing fresh visions. Critics and the general public are excited by its inventiveness and aesthetic appeal. Its difference from traditional Aboriginal art has caused much controversy. Hetti Perkins introduces contemporary Aboriginal art, its themes and the issues. Geoff Bardon gives a personal account of the beginnings of the Papunya painting movement when he encouraged senior men to paint their Dreaming Stories in acrylics. Michael Nelson Jakamarra, recognized internationally as one of the outstanding artists from the Papuya central desert community, talks about his country and his art.
results.title_for_label: Tradition and change: art from the desert
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service

results.title: Lord of the bush
results.brief_description: Lord Alistair McAlpine, entrepreneur and Treasurer of Margaret Thatcher’s Conservative Party is opening Broome for Tourism. Examines the issues that have been raised including Aboriginal land rights and the conflict between tourist developments and conservation. Interviews colourful Broome identities and their reactions to the changes.

results.title: Oondamooroo: a profile of Ernie Dingo
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, Don Featherstone Productions and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: The Aboriginal actor Ernie Dingo talks about his career, his origins, influences on his life and his feelings about his aboriginality. Features excerpts from his work on stage and screen, interviews with friends, mentors, family and wife and shows him at work teaching Aboriginal children to develop self-respect and white children to understand Aboriginal culture and history. An engaging look at an impressive and likeable personality.
